Mary Beth and John Tinker are coming to Iowa to celebrate the 50th anniversary of their student rights black armband win at the U.S. Supreme Court. Join us!

Dear ##SM_RULE_360 Email Salutation##,

During the Vietnam War, 13-year-old Mary Beth and 16-year-old John Tinker were suspended from their Des Moines schools for wearing black armbands to protest the war. With the help of the ACLU of Iowa, they sued and changed the course of student free speech forever.

On February 24, 1969, the U.S. Supreme Court issued its landmark decision in Tinker v. Des Moines. As the Court famously wrote, a student's freedom of expression should not end at the schoolhouse gate.

Now Mary Beth and John will be back in Iowa to celebrate with a series of events in public schools, colleges, and more. Join us for an event near you!

Celebration of Student Free Speech and Press Rights
Saturday, February 23, 4 - 6 p.m.
RayGun, 505 E. Grand, Des Moines
Join student journalists and advisors from Iowa, Parkland, and Texas for a reception on student rights. The fun and famous T-shirt maker has created a special T-shirt for sale at this reception: â€œDon't Tinker With My Rights." This event is free and open to the public. Learn more.

Stand Up! Speak Up! Youth & The First Amendment
Monday, February 25, 7:30 p.m.
ISU Memorial Union, Great Hall, Ames
Mary Beth and John will discuss the significance of their historic Supreme Court case, especially in the current political climate, at a panel discussion moderated by Mark Stringer. Learn more.

Tinker v. Des Moines: Protecting the Voices of Our Youth
Tuesday, February 26, 7:30 p.m.
Old Capitol, University of Iowa, Iowa City
Join the Tinkers and the ACLU in a panel discussion highlighting the significance of the historic decision and what it means in the current political climate. Learn more.

See a complete listing of Tinker Events in Iowa.

We look forward to seeing you there,

ACLU of Iowa
